dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soft music. A classy joint. Below the tables, WE PAN well-heeled feet nuzzling. Finally we SETTLE ON:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE SNEAKERS sitting opposite FANCY HIGH HEELS. These feet aren't nuzzling. There's distance here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULL UP, REVEALING CAL WEAVER (42) and his wife, TRACY  (41). A handsome couple. He'd be JFK to her Jackie O...  if he gave a shit. Unfortunately, he doesn't (i.e.: white sneakers in fancy French restaurant).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal pulls out READING GLASSES, looks at the menu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm full. You were right, hon. I shouldn't have eaten all that bread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to just share a dessert?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy is lost in thought, gazing at a menu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay, babe? You seem out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm just thinking about what I want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too. Okay, let's say it at the same time. One. Two. Three...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want a divorce. Creme Brulee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JESSICA (17) chases after MOLLY (9). Jessica's skinny, wears glasses, a hipster T-shirt. In five years, she's going to make all the boys' heads spin. But not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna getcha! I'm gonna  getcha!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She grabs Molly and tickles her. Molly SQUEALS with  delight. As she kicks... SMASH! A picture falls off the nearby console. Jessica picks it up:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal and Tracy. This is their house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, my fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, kiddo, it's getting late, let's get you to bed before your parents get home. Don't give me the puppy eyes, you little maniac. Go brush your teeth!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Molly GIGGLES, RUNS upstairs. Once Molly's gone, Jessica looks at the photo. She eyes Cal affectionately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, TWO YOUNG PROFESSIONAL WOMEN drink and laugh at a table. HANNAH (24) is clearly buzzed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care. I love him and given the opportunity, I'd have his babies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her best friend, LIZ (29), LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously? Conan O'Brien? You'd do Conan O'Brien?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just saying, Richard's a lot  of things: successful, smart...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boring, workaholic, sexually  repressed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he's not very funny, that's  all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, you want funny, go watch `Cosby' reruns. You want a good lay, go get yourself some of... that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She motions off to the side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hot piece that's been checking you out for the last hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CROWD PARTS, revealing: JACOB PALMER (32). The  smoothest, coolest son-of-a-bitch you've ever seen. He tilts his glass at them, toasting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, Cal sits in the passenger seat, dazed. A "to- go" box from the French restaurant in his lap. Tracy drives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you going to say anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost twenty-five years of marriage, you have nothing to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him. He turns to her, about to say something, then... stops himself. Turns back forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's silent. Devastating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, Jessica (the baby-sitter) stops at a bedroom door. She hears MUSIC coming from inside, puts her ear  to the door. It's Lady Gaga. It's awful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles, knocks and opens the door at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, your sister's asleep, just checking you're alive --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She SCREAMS as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROBBIE WEAVER (13), quickly covers himself up. He was  masturbating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close the door!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: who slams the door shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Robbie! I didn't see  anything, I swear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie lies there frozen, horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, where Liz and Hannah keep drinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Hannah. Your life is just so... PG-13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah's mouth drops open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My life is not PG-13!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It so is. You've never left LA.  You pass the bar you're gonna be, what, a patent lawyer, probably married to that snooze-fest Richard. I just worry about you is all. Hell, you've resorted to fantasizing about Conan `Ginger-  Dick' O'Brien.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks like a carrot, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn. It's Jacob Palmer (the stud from earlier).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Who looks like a carrot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conan O'Brien. My friend Hannah thinks he's sexy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think your friend Hannah is sexy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't really just say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty sure I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-three next month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you should know by now that cheesy pick-up lines don't work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob sits down at their table, uninvited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I find you incredibly sexy. It's a fact, not a cheesy pick-up line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are many attractive women in this bar -- including your friend here -- and I've been unable to take my eyes off you, only you, for the past two hours. Again: not a cheesy pick-up line, just a fact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Answer this quickly, without thinking about your answer: do you find me attractive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah doesn't flinch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, she does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm an accomplished lover. If you come home with me, I am confident you will leave satisfied.  Multiple times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got to be kiddi--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll make love and it will be amazing. You'll laugh afterwards and say `I never do this kind of thing.' Then you'll do it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is. So now I'm going to ask if I can buy you another drink. If you say yes, we'll have one more cocktail each -- just enough to start losing inhibitions, not enough to get sloppy, after all: I promised to satisfy you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Multiple times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. So, here we go, Hannah: can I buy you a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah and Liz share a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you expect me to say to that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margarita, rocks, salt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She STANDS, grabs her coat and Liz's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, time to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liz doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go home with you, you can call me Hannah, I don't give a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liz!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering to him) Another time, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GIGGLING, the girls leave the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still driving, Tracy looks at Cal. He remains silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm unhappy, Cal. I've tried not to be. We've been married so long, somewhere we became... stagnant, you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He keeps staring straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, you're not talking and you  know that only makes me talk more.  Maybe that's good, maybe that's  good. Okay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's this person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been spending time together.  Lunches, meetings, that kind of  stuff...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. She closes her eyes tightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I slept with him. Kind of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy opens one eye, taking a peek. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no kind of. I can't believe I  said kind of. That's just not  something you do in a kind of way.  I slept with someone. There. I  said it. I slept with someone.  Oh God. It's the worst thing I've  ever done but it feels so good to  say out loud. I slept with  someone. I SLEPT with someone. I  slept with SOMEONE. I slept with  ... please stop me, please say  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David Jacobowitz. From work. You met him at the Christmas party.  You remember that party? They had  the giant paper-machГ© wreath? I  kept asking the decorator how he  made it? You wore that sweater --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, Cal speaks --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last person in the world I'd ever want to hurt was you, Cal --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you keep talking, I'm going to get out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the fact that I did, that it  could happen at all, I think it  just shows how broken we are and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like that, Cal OPENS THE DOOR to the moving car and, simply, steps out. Tracy SCREAMS as Cal goes flying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She screeches to a stop as he tumbles to the curb in her rearview mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy runs to him. He's on the curb, BLOODIED but okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you out of your mind!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up at her, pleading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll leave tonight, I'll sign whatever you want me to sign, if you'll just stop talking about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She touches his bloody forehead, affectionate. There's still something here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands, limps back to the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, Jessica sits on the living room couch. Robbie ENTERS, stands there. He's a precocious, adorable, masturbation-addicted, thirteen-year-old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry that you had to see that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She keeps staring straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should have knocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. After a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the record: I think about you while I do it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a picture of you and I look at it the whole time --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, Jessica. And I know you're seventeen, and I know I just turned thirteen, which is the  same age as your little brother,  and you're technically my baby- sitter, but someday soon our age difference will be inconsequential which is good because...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm pretty sure you're my soulmate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops, looks at him and smiles gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Robbie --

dialogues.speaker: LIZ, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: We're home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jessica jumps off the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Mr. and Mrs. Weaver. How was dinner...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God, Mr. Weaver, you're bleeding. Why are you bleeding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Weaver told me she wants a divorce so I jumped out of the car. Hope the kids behaved. Come on, I'll drive you home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie steps INTO FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. I didn't know you were here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're getting divorced?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you jumped out of a car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moving car, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry you found out this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry you jumped out of a car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jessica, you got your coat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal drives now. Jessica in the front. Awkward. Finally, Cal starts talking to himself. Almost shell-  shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll talk to the kids tomorrow. Tell them we're separating. Just separating. We'll do it together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have to tell Nanna. Uch, she's gonna be crushed. But not right now. She's got enough to worry about...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He trails off. Another long beat of silence, then he remembers his company and turns toward Jessica.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, I hear Stanford early  admission, huh. I know your dad is so proud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're bleeding real bad, Mr. Weaver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes to touch his eye. Out of nowhere... he starts BANGING THE SHIT out of his steering wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David Jacobowitz! Are you kidding me!? DAVID FUCKING JACOBOWITZ!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He calms down, slowly. Pulls up to a DRIVEWAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jessica reaches for the door, but stops. She takes a deep breath, adorable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Weaver, I know you don't know me very well, but I've been baby- sitting for your family for three years. You're the nicest dad of any of the families I baby-sit for, by a country mile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're funny, and you're always really generous, and you're the only dad who's excited -- genuinely excited -- to check on his kids when he gets home from dinner. Now I like Mrs. Weaver, I like her a lot, but if she wants to divorce you, well... then I think she's batshit crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal smiles, distracted but grateful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In fact -- and, I hope this doesn't make you uncomfortable -- I think I've even developed a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey: do me a favor -- can you not mention what's going on between Mrs. Weaver and I to your parents? It's probably better they hear it from us. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jessica awkwardly gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Jessica? Thanks for listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles, turns back. She freezes when she sees... He's holding CASH out the window to pay her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You put this to that fake ID you'll need up at Stanford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with a sad wink, he drives off -- leaving her standing there, lovelorn and forty-five dollars richer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal sits at the bar, drinking away his sorrows. He's disheveled, a bit wobbly. He motions for the BARTENDER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another vodka cranberry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Just... yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GIRL (30s) approaches the bar. Cal taps her shoulder, a drunken train-wreck waiting to happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife is having intercourse with someone who isn't me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very nice of you to say. She just told me tonight, obviously it came as a bit of a shock and you're not listening anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Girl has turned back to a group of friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet you wouldn't ignore me if I were David Jacobowitz. My wife doesn't ignore David Jacobowitz. (to no one)  She screws him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something catches Cal's eye across the bar. We PAN TO...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: wearing his two thousand dollar suit, he's now got TWO  BEAUTIFUL WOMEN fawning over him at his table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal takes him in for a long beat, turns back to the  bartender, and decides:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gay.  15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know these places: basically a "strip" of identical  housing units -- usually occupied by newly-divorced dads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WOMAN (60s) gives Cal the tour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it's pretty no-frills. Unit 2  is a lot like unit 1 except you're  downstairs so... the ground is  closer. Which is nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The most depressing, empty, beige place ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess the price is right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, tons of divorced guys  here. You'll fit right in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal SIGHS, un-enthused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooh, the gym has an elliptical  machine... I assume you want to  get back in shape?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal looks down, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great! I'll let you know when  they fix it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal sits at his desk, doing paperwork. His BOSS ENTERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal, I just got the weekly sales  report, good good good! You  really killed this quarter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep it up you're going to be  sitting in my seat by year's end.  Really great, Cal. Seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who told you Tracy and I were  getting a divorce?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Divorce! That's it. Amy heard  you crying in the bathroom. We  all thought it was cancer. Thank  God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to go buy furniture now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal stands, EXITS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go for it!  (then, calling after)  It could have been cancer, buddy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal is sitting on a plain, faux-modern couch. He's  staring into space. A SALESMAN APPROACHES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife is sleeping with David  Jacobowitz. I need a couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooh, I understand. Can I give you  a word of advice, one divorced man  to another? If you don't mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the matching chaise, killer  deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pats the adjacent piece. Cal processes this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want it in beige.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll write you up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal's back at the bar, sipping on his drink. He looks  absolutely exhausted. He looks across the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At his usual table, Jacob is now wooing a NEW WOMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal shakes his head, amazed at this guy's chutzpah. A  GUY grabs the open bar stool next to Cal. Cal reacts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no, I'm sorry, I'm waiting for  a friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been holding the seat for  an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, my wife is screwing  David Jacobowitz so eat me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy shrugs, walks away. Cal looks at his watch, puts  a napkin on his drink, and stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal pees. Jacob steps INTO FRAME in the adjacent urinal.  Cal does a friendly "I'm peeing next to you" nod. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't help but notice that you're  always surrounded by women.  Multiple women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob doesn't even turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm getting divorced. Or, in the  process. Gonna be single again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any advice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob zips, flushes, turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't start conversations with  people while they're pissing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks away, washes his hands, EXITS. A beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So gay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal's a few drinks in now. The door to the bar opens as  BERNIE (late 40s) rushes in. An oak tree of a man. He's  carrying a SHOPPING BAG.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I'm late, I had to pick  something up from Macy's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it, here, sit,  I've been guarding this stool with  my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernie sits, looks uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good to see you, man. I've  called you a few times. It's been  a rough couple of days, obviously.  Nothing I could use more than my  old pal Bernie to unload on. Hey,  we should play racquetball, when's  the last time we played  racquetball?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claire won't let me be friends  with you anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal takes this in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She said we had to choose between  you and Tracy. I chose you. She  said no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls a WRAPPED PACKAGE from the bag, hands it to Cal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's cologne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you breaking up with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claire's waiting in the car.  Um... there's a gift receipt in  there. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernie stands, awkwardly. He pats Cal on the shoulder,  lingers a beat too long, then simply turns and EXITS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal is left alone. He raises a finger at the Bartender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have anything with a worm  in it? Because I'd like a gallon  of that now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Legs crossed, martini in hand, he's been watching Cal get dumped this whole time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He PANS UP from Cal's feet. The white sneakers. Bad navy blue dress socks. Dad khakis. An ill-fitting, untucked, dress shirt. Half-lidded eyes. Rumpled hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob shakes his head. Jesus Christ. He says something  to THE WOMAN who currently sits at the table. She nods,  gets up and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Bartender pours him a second shot. He's now  showing pictures from his wallet to the Bartender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my youngest, Molly. Her two favorite things are High School Musical and her mother. I hate both of her two favorite things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SHARP WHISTLE interrupts. Cal turns, sees Jacob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob motions for Cal to come over. Every move Jacob makes is practiced, perfectly cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal points at himself: "Me?" Jacob nods: "Yep." Cal SHRUGS, stands, and wobbles over towards Jacob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob Palmer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to buy you a drink, Cal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already have a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me buy you a drink, Cal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob motions to the Bartender who NODS. Cal SITS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife is cheating on me with --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David Jacobowitz, yes, Cal, I've heard. We've all heard. For the last two nights, I've watched you  batter every poor soul in this bar with your sad-sack loser sob story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal takes this in. He STANDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what, I don't need this

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down, Cal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal sits. Jacob's that powerful. Cal's that drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal, I'm going to make you an offer, it's probably the best offer you're ever going to get, and you're extremely drunk, so it's wildly important that you don't answer until I've finished and you've taken a few moments to process what I'm saying. Do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal goes to answer, Jacob holds up a finger. Cal stops himself. Once he's settled, Jacob continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I said, I've been watching you for two days now and I can say,  without hesitation, that you are the sorriest man I've ever seen in my life -- don't interrupt, Cal, it's the truth, and you need to hear it. You're sitting there with your Supercut haircut, getting drunk on watered down vodka-cranberries like a fourteen- year-old girl, wearing a 41R jacket when you should be wearing a 40L -- I don't know if I want to help you or euthanize you -- stop drinking out of the goddamn straw, Cal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal stops drinking from the wimpy red straw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You asked me for advice before,  Cal, so I'm going to help you. I  don't know why. Maybe I'm just bored. Maybe all my friends have abandoned me for wives and children and labradoodle puppies, who cares why? Why doesn't matter. The point is, you've got a good face, and a good head of hair, and I'm bored as hell and need a project. So if you want, I'm going to help you rediscover your manhood. Do you remember when it was that you lost it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal shakes "no."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't matter, we'll find it. And when we do, when I'm through with you, that wife of yours is going to rue the day she decided to give up on you too early. That's my offer. What do you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal stares at him blankly. A long beat of silence. Cal goes for a drink, almost uses the straw... then catches himself. He puts down the drink. Looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mall food court, Thursday, six o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob downs his drink, nods at THE WOMAN (now nearby).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ready to go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods, subservient, and follows him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal shakes his head, picks up his drink, and slurps the rest of his vodka cranberry out of the straw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A well-maintained yard, bordered by shrubs and bushes. A  long driveway runs parallel to the yard. A medium-sized  U-HAUL is parked in the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal EXITS the back door, carrying a BOX. He loads it  into the U-haul and takes a last look back at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A weathered playground sits off to the side. You can  tell it hasn't been used in quite some time. Baseball  equipment lays all over, the site of many father-son  catches. An oft-used barbecue next to the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can tell a lot about this family from seeing this  backyard. You like this family a lot from seeing this  backyard.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Cal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal looks up. Tracy approaches. She's wearing sweats.  It's pretty obvious that she's been crying. Awkward  silence. Neither knows what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted to say that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her voice cracks. She turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gathers herself. Cal steps forward. Instinct tells  him to comfort his wife but he can't anymore and he stops himself. She realizes this. There's something harsh and  complicated about the reality of it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy looks at the U-HAUL, wipes her eyes and tries to  lighten things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want me to back that thing  out of the driveway for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have trouble in reverse is  all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was two times --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three if you count my father's  foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did that on purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They smile, in rhythm for a moment. Then they realize,  stop smiling. Cal turns awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once I'm settled, I'll get the  kids so they can see the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks to the truck. Tracy's voice stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'm have a mid-life crisis  maybe. Can women have mid-life  crisis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make sure the lawn gets enough  water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the movies it's always men  having them and buying ridiculous  yellow Porsches, but I'm not a man  and I really don't want a yellow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to fertilize once a  month. Not twice a month, not  once every two months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes a deep breath, finding her balance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got married so young, Cal. And  I'm forty-one. And that's so much  older than I thought I'd be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sprinklers turn off behind  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I got really upset with an  umpire at Molly's t-ball game last  month -- like really upset, like I  screamed at him and wished he  would die -- and I started feeling  like the person I promised I  wouldn't turn into, you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it rains a lot, you need to  shut off the automatic setting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we haven't been us, not for a  long time. And I don't know when  you and I stopped being `us'  but... I mean, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal finally turns and looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it was when you screwed  David Jacobowitz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ouch. Tracy's face registers the blow, but she nods:  she also understands it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make sure my azaleas get enough  sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal turns, gets in the U-HAUL, and backs out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And immediately crashes into the neighboring FENCE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal leads in Molly and Robbie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, well, this is it. What do you think? Didn't have a lot of time to house-hunt, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look around his depressing, beige apartment. A  pathetic TV plays the Disney Channel in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a second bedroom with twin beds so you two can stay over whenever you want! Anytime!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... you're like, actually going  to live here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Molly looks like she's going to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, hey. Come on now, you'll visit all the time. Every weekend. It won't be that bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you love us anymore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal takes Molly's face in his hands, starts tearing up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, baby. What's happening with your mommy and I... it's not what either of us wanted, not what either of us planned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you need to understand that you kids have done nothing wron--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She bolts past Cal to the TV, where ZAC EFRON is on- screen, prancing about in a basketball uniform. Robbie and Cal stand there, awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't take it personally. That show's like crack to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal NODS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I say something with a curse? One time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie NODS, takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love is fucked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal LAUGHS, a bit of tension relieved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that so? You in love, buddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you must know --

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Ding dong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn -- it's Jessica, the baby-sitter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is she doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, right, hey, Jess, thanks for

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back to Robbie) I have to run out really quickly, just for a few hours, and your mother wants you to stay here while she's out hooking --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is... nice, Mr. Weaver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, well, that's a generous adjective, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyhow, Jess is gonna keep an eye on you guys for a few.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I don't need a babysitter! She's only four years older than me! You need to know that! She needs to know that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, buddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal musses Robbie's hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My little boy's growing up, Jess. He's in love already, can you believe it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uch. Robbie thumps the wall with his head, dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Molly, say bye-bye to Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No response, she's glued to the television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm, uh... I decided to take a class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great, Mr. Weaver. It's a  difficult time for you, it's important that you find new interests, try new things, maybe things you'd never have considered trying before...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal looks down, Jessica has her hand on his shoulder. It's a bit odd. She realizes, takes it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, well... Molly, last chance!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Molly is still locked on Efron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my angel. Back in a few.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Dad --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door slams. Robbie stands there with Jessica, awkward. Tries to maintain some semblance of cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need a baby-sitter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, Robbie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An awkward beat, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you so much --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal pulls into the parking lot, grabs a space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ENTERS, still going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell am I doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks past a CHEESECAKE FACTORY. Inside is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah (girl from the bar who Jacob tried picking up).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's sitting at a table with Liz (her friend) and a GROUP OF REALLY BORING WHITE PEOPLE in suits. There are SMALL GIFTS in front of Hannah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holding her hand is an average guy (33), her boyfriend, RICHARD. We PICK UP mid-conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're wrong. I think that's Tucker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no. Chris Rock is the stand-up comedian. Chris Tucker is the actor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it racist that I can't tell them apart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liz nods her head "yes" at Hannah. Hannah stifles a LAUGH. Liz stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Richard: thank you for inviting me to Hannah's `goodbye' party. The conversation has been riveting, like stepping back in  time. Before I go, a toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds up her glass, toasting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweetie: go into your hole and  study your cute little ass off for that bar exam. We'll see you when you emerge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's gonna kick that bar's butt!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the dorks CHEER. Liz SHRUGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liz CHUGS her drink, turns to Hannah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll walk you out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before they clear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Liz? When my girl passes, we're gonna have another little celebration, right here. Hope you can make it. It's going to be a special night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard, you just give me a heads- up so I can get really drunk before-hand, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah leads Liz out of the restaurant, WHISPERS:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear that? `It's going to be a special night.' You think he's going to propose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the Cheesecake Factory? Oh God, I hope not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Do you really want him to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah SHRUGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well... Jesus. Really?  (with a shrug) Okay. Not my life, I love you, call me if you need anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liz KISSES her goodbye, EXITS. Hannah looks at her  table. Everyone is typing on their BLACKBERRIES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She SIGHS, heads to rejoin them. 31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, Cal sees Jacob, standing against a pole in the food court. Jacob is eating pizza, cool as ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're late. (then, offering) Sbarro's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks. So what exactly are

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much money can you afford to spend on clothes today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno. Five hundred?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll start with shoes. Let me see those sneakers you're wearing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal holds up his foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take them off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal bends down, takes one off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other one too, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal does as he's told. Jacob holds out his hands. Cal SHRUGS, hands Jacob the shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob simply turns and throws them over the railing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you in a fraternity, Cal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those were my favorite shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you Steve Jobs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'm not Steve Jobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you don't need to walk around in New Balance Sneaker, ever. Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal (barefoot) follows Jacob around the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think this whole thing might have been a bad idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob ignores him, grabs a pair of BLACK DRESS SHOES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any man can rebuild his entire wardrobe with sixteen simple items.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha! I think I read that in GQ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did. I wrote it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob CHUCKLES. Cal CHUCKLES back, clearly unsure what the chuckle symbolizes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Numbers one and two: pair of dress shoes, pair of loafers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal is looking at a pair of ARGYLE SOCKS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I'm lost: do you really write for GQ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob slaps Cal's hand, knocking the socks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your credit card please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We watch as Jacob narrates the wardrobe essentials (and as Cal's arms get progressively fuller) in each store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal gets fitted.

dialogues.speaker: JACOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Two suits: one black, one grey. One sports jacket, navy preferred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob leans in toward the tailor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it in there... and there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal holds jeans in front of him, eyes them suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: JACOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: One pair of quality jeans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are two hundred and thirty dollars. Can't we just go to the Gap?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up. Jacob is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal runs outside. Jacob is already halfway to the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry! Don't leave!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob immediately heads back inside and answers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Cal. We can't just go to the Gap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with the Gap?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Hell, every store is the Gap, that's what's wrong with the Gap, Cal. It's lowest common denominator. Be better than the fucking Gap, Cal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob holds up a pair of beige slacks.

dialogues.speaker: JACOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: One pair of chinos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHING. A cash register DINGS.

dialogues.speaker: JACOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Four dress shirts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHING. CHING. CHING. CHING. Cal's arms are filling.

dialogues.speaker: JACOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Three casual button-downs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHING. CHING. CHING. In a dressing room shirts come flying over the wall at Cal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal struggles to get a sweater over his neck.

dialogues.speaker: JACOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Two v-neck cashmere sweaters, and finally, a long overcoat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal stands there in an overcoat and sweater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very warm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob leads Cal through the store. He tosses him a TUBE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You rub this in around your eyes every night and every morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does it do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It gives you x-ray vision, Cal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It tightens things up. The skin around your eyes looks like Milton Berle's ballsack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal stops, examines his eyes in a mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God, it does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal is getting his hair cut at a fancy salon. The HAIRDRESSER is young, hip, and beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like to use a number four on the sides and the back, go longer on the top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, okay. Thanks for that, Vidal Sassoon. Tiffany, hon? Scissor  cut, tight on sides, get him some texture up top, take off about... He touches Cal's hair, measures it between his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eww.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... inch off the top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tiffany starts chopping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob and Tiffany wait for Cal (inside a changing room).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you putting on?

dialogues.speaker: CAL, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Items one, three, eleven, and fourteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfect. (then, to Tiffany) You smell great by the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay, I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She GIGGLES. Cal calls out.

dialogues.speaker: CAL, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Seriously? You just ask her out like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Cal, just like that.

dialogues.speaker: CAL, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: And it works?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CAL, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I feel kind of stupid but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DRESSING ROOM DOOR opens. We TILT UP... FROM expensive shoes, TO pants, TO fitted sweater over a fitted shirt and bright tie. The new haircut...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A new man. He looks... unbelievable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I blouse out the shirt a little? I like to blouse out my shirts a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, Cal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd fuck him, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, probably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tiffany! (then, realizing) You would!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tiffany SHRUGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see that, Cal? The simple act of opening your mouth instantly causes Tiffany to lose interest in sleeping with you. Your personality is actually your weakest link.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal takes this in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's the meanest thing anyone's ever said to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Cal. The meanest thing anyone's ever said to you is this: your wife cheated on you because you lost sight of what it took to keep her content at home -- as a man, as a husband, and probably as a lover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal's lower lip begins to quiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay, that was meaner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal sits next to Jacob. Cal is wearing his new "outfit."  He looks great, but not yet comfortable in his new  "gear."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob, on the other hand, looks like he's walked out of a men's magazine. And he knows it. Cal looks at Jacob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I notice you only button your shirts up, like, halfway. I can't pull that off, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Listen, Cal, I'm going to be  calling women over to our table shortly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal rubs his hands together, nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should have some background on each other, no? I'm in insurance, more on the corporate side. My kids are --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal, the only thing I care less about than corporate insurance are your kids. Here's the only thing  I need to know: how many women have you been with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sexually?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In my entire life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, synchronized swimming. Yes,  Cal. Sexually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal thinks. He MUMBLES to himself, counting it out on one hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles at Jacob proudly when he has to move the count to a second hand. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob CHORTLES. But Cal just stares at him blankly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow, okay... wow. (then, checking)  Not at a time? Total?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? I married young. We met in high school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles, remembering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy was so damn beautiful. You know those women, the ones who can be wildly sexy and unbelievably cute all at once? I never knew how she did that. I still don't know how she does it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, we had a bit of a hiccup our senior year but we made it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal, I literally stopped listening at `Tracy.' Okay, here we go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a bit emotional) I miss my wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, Cal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A YOUNG WOMAN slides into the booth at Jacob's side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Jacob Palmer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal extends his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Weaver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I get you a drink, Amy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: gets handed over to: a NEW GIRL, on a NEW NIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about yourself. What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it really matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It does to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up. He looks completely earnest, repeats:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It does to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN TO CAL: just sitting there watching, horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now with NEWER GIRL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's when I started writing the column for LA Weekly. God,  how long have I been talking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I'm going to be honest: it's getting late and I think you're interesting. I also think you're one of those rare women who manages to be both wildly sexy and incredibly cute all at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mouth agape. That was his line!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get out of here. I know it's forward of me but just... I think we should get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She thinks, then NODS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we should get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we should get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: waving goodbye awkwardly as Jacob leaves with each of the girls (IN QUICK CUTS). Finally:

dialogues.speaker: 38A CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Cal just sits there, completely alone. But then A PRETTY  GIRL arrives at his table. Cal looks up, smiles. She smiles back, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She drops THE BILL on the table. She's a waitress. And he's been left with the tab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie Weaver sits at his 8th grade desk. In the b.g., we hear a FEMALE TEACHER drone on about The Scarlet Letter. Under his desk, Robbie is TEXTING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: receiving the text.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The text: "Hi, Jessica. FYI: Demi Moore is 15 yrs older than Ashton K. They seem really happy. Love, Robbie."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her phone BEEPS with a NEW TEXT: "P.S. did you know Demi  Moore starred in the movie version of The Scarlet  Letter?"  Her phone BEEPS a third time: "She shows boob :-)"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She SIGHS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleased with himself. The FEMALE TEACHER drones on in  the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: While Hester is forced to wear a scarlet `A' as punishment for adultery, Reverend Dimmesdale's `A' is self-inflicted --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie's PHONE BEEPS. A "NEW MESSAGE." Robbie smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The text: "Robbie: please stop. U r making me very uncomfortable."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie stares at the screen, crestfallen.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Weaver? Are we interrupting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie looks up: the WHOLE CLASS is staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Weaver!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly, Robbie stands. We HEAD IN TIGHT ON him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to talk about The Scarlet Letter, Mrs. Thompson? Here you go: the `A' they're both wearing -- I think it stands for ASSHOLE. Wanna know why? Because they're in love, and love is for stupid ASSHOLES. So thanks for choosing this book, Mrs. Thompson, because this is what I need right now: to  read a boring, confusing book about a bunch of stupid assholes who fell in love, like assholes, and then had to die, like assholes. I'm sorry for cursing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy works at her desk. A KNOCK at her door interrupts.  A TALL MAN (40's) stands there: DAVID JACOBOWITZ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a second?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, David. I'm just a little  swamped right now so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He closes the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been avoiding me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I haven't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ran away in the other  direction when you saw me coming  down the hall yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're very fast by the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She SIGHS, gives up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ran track in high school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That must be it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about you and Cal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm also not sorry, if I'm being  completely honest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to make sure you know how  much I like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I do --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot. Just to clarify. I like  you a lot. I had no intention of  falling for a married woman. I  just wanted someone to go to lunch  with who didn't make me want to  shoot myself in the face. But we  started having lunch, and talking,  and suddenly I was an accountant  who was popping out of bed in the  morning, excited to get to work.  That doesn't happen to  accountants. Ever. I've checked  with other accountants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So when the time is right for you  to get back out there again,  officially, I just... I'd like to  throw my hat in the ring.  Officially. That sounded weird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy LAUGHS lightly, leans forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, you've been a great friend  to me. And you were the first man  in a very long time to make me  feel... noticed, I guess? What  happened between us that night...  it meant something to me. You  weren't the only one excited to  come to work lately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But now, when I see you, all I see  is his face. All I see when I  look at you is what I did to my  marriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's losing it, wipes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see this? I'm saving you from  disaster, David, `cause you're  asking to pre-board the Titanic.  Honestly, do you really want any  part of this?  Before he can answer... BUZZ! It's Tracy's phone.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Your son's school on two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy quickly picks up phone. As she talks, David  scribbles something on a postcard, EXITS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, okay. No, I understand.  Of course, right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She HANGS UP, looks at the Post-It. It reads, simply:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Yes." Tracy looks up, but David is gone.  46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie sits, waiting. Tracy EMERGES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling back in) Yes, of course. Absolutely, Principal Sapienza, it won't happen again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She closes the door behind her, looks to Robbie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She SIGHS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been a rough couple of weeks, you deserve a freebie. C'mon, I have to get back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk out together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They still make kids read The Scarlet Letter, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie NODS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd really think someone would have written something better by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie LAUGHS, the tension broken a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie wheels around in an office chair as Tracy tries to work behind her desk. He stops, noticing a PHOTO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an older picture of CAL AND TRACY. They look happy.  Very much in love. Tracy notices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess I should take it down, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy NODS. She places the picture face down gently.  She tries to return to her work, but can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is he? I've spoken to him but only about bills, or you kids, but... how is he, really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, that's unfair. Ignore me, I'm almost done here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns back to her work. After a beat:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's dressing a lot better. Going out a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Well, good. That's... really good. (then, covering) We'll get take-out for dinner tonight, okay? Think about what you're in the mood for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie hesitates, then adds:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's sad. He looks better, but... sadder, too, I think. You know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I guess I'm pretty sad, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard you crying the other night  and... I didn't know what to do.  I'm thirteen years old and... can  you just tell me what I'm supposed  to do in that situation? I didn't  want to Google it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles, shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God, baby, you're so much like  me it's scary. You wound up with  all my stuff, Robbie. I'm so  sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm okay with being like you, Mom.  I like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts down her pen. Smiles sadly at Robbie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my fault, what happened with  your father. It's grown-up stuff  that I can't talk about but... it's my fault. Not his. So just... be good to him, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be okay, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You promise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He NODS, the most soulful thirteen-year-old ever.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID JACOBOWITZ, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey, they need you in the conference room for a sec... oh, sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look up. It's David. Tracy gathers herself,  stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, this is my son, Robbie. Robbie, this is David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We work together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie takes him in, shakes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be right back, okay, honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awkward. Really awkward. Tracy starts to say something, thinks better of it, and EXITS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David moves into the room, sits down opposite Robbie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Robbie... I hear you're quite the soccer player.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, David... I hear you broke up my parents' marriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He LAUGHS awkwardly, shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are David Jacobowitz, right? From accounting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, yes I am --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the thing, David: in the end, she winds up back with my dad. He's better than you, in every category except probably  math. And she still loves him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie props the PHOTO of Tracy and Cal back up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Robbie --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I know what you're thinking: `he's just in 8th grade, what does he know about love?' I know a lot more than you think, David. Just today, I had a meltdown, almost gave up on the love of my life. My dad's having his meltdown now,  but long-term? He won't stop fighting for my mom any more than I won't stop sending Jessica texts that make her uncomfortable. And you need to know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy RE-ENTERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ready to go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy, can we do Chinese for  dinner tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy waves to David as she and Robbie EXIT, leaving him  stunned in the middle of her office, staring at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE PHOTO OF CAL AND TRACY that Robbie has left directly in his line of sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bushes rustle. Once, then twice. It's Cal, sneaking  into the backyard. He takes a covert look inside the  house. All is quiet. He gets to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- He spreads FERTILIZER on the grass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Trims some bushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Picks off some petals from some dying flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the strangest goddamn thing you've ever seen.  Finally, he finishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Content. His yard may not be his anymore, but it's back  in order. As he takes it all in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LIGHT pops on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal DIVES into a SHRUB.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another night at the bar: Cal's in his position, Jacob in his. Cal sips his drink, staring aimlessly forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob looks at Cal. Cal looks great, more comfortable in his new "skin" than when we left him. He's drinking a martini, rather than a red-strawed vodka cranberry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WAITRESS passes. Without speaking, Cal taps the rim of the glass, silently requesting a refill. It's a cool, practiced move... and he did it instinctively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob smiles, leans forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're ready, Cal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To talk to a woman, take a woman home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no. No, I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been watching me do it for two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, I've been watching LeBron James for years, doesn't mean I can suddenly dunk a basketball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal, do you remember the part in Karate Kid, where Mr. Miagi keeps having the kid wax the car and the  kid gets all bent out of shape because he doesn't see the point, but the movements were actually  building blocks for throwing and blocking punches?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God. Are you going to make me fight someone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob stretches his neck, trying his patience:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal, what's the first thing I do when a woman sits down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ask if you can buy her a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what if she says no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You order her a drink anyway, let it sit there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When she asks me a question about myself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You deflect it back to her. You never answer questions about yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what happens?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They talk about themselves. A lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what do I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You act really interested. You nod a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And at the end of the night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You compliment them, then you ask if they'd like to come back to your place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I ask?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You confidently tell them you'd like them to come back to your place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy shit! You Mr. Miagi'd me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob BOWS to Cal, Japanese style. A PRETTY WOMAN stands near their table. Jacob stands, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, and no talking about your job,  your children, your pathetic sexual history, or David Jacobowitz. Okay, here we go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, no, I'm not ready for -- (then, to woman) Hi!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob has pulled her over. She's attractive, mid-  thirties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal, this is Kate. Kate, Cal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob NODS at Cal ("you've got this") and leaves them.  Kate SITS. Cal smiles at Kate, nervous. She smiles back. Cal MOTIONS for a waitress in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I buy you a drink, Kate?

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (PRETTY WOMAN)
dialogues.text: Oh. No thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal smiles, portrays confidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm buying you a drink anyway, Kate, so you might as well tell me what you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really, thank you but it's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm guessing you're a vodka girl, am I right? Yeah? A nice dirty martini? No, no, no: a Grey Goose, rocks, extra lime? C'mon,  one drink! Picture those ice cubes clinking together. Mmmm. Can't you taste it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I can but... I'm, uh, five years sober so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal's face drops. The WAITRESS approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I get --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. We don't want anything. Don't come back here ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Waitress leaves, confused. Kate looks around, uncomfortable. She tries small-talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... what do you do, Cal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do, Kate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked you first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked you second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She LAUGHS lightly, thinks he's being funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously, what do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously, what do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now it's getting a little weird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a teacher. Now, c'mon: what do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal NODS, exaggerated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teacher. Interesting. I'm very interested in teaching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, are you not going to tell me what you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's still nodding, as if fascinated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A teacher with an alcohol dependency no less, I bet that's actually more common than people realize...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should get back to my friends --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kate STANDS. Cal puts his face in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry! I'm supposed to deflect your questions... oh screw it: I'm in corporate insurance. And I have children. Plural. More than one. The only thing I have ONE of, is sexual partners, that would be the woman I recently separated from because she was cheating on me with David Jacobowitz who I wasn't supposed to tell you about either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kate turns back, curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you supposed to tell me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know: that you're a perfect combination of sexy and cute -- it was something I said about my wife that's since been corrupted. But I'm tired, and I'm at least fifteen years older than you, and this sweater is called slim fitting but it's really just uncomfortable and itchy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I'm a perfect combination of sexy and cute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what you took away from that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles, sits back down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow, an actual honest man. I don't know what to do with that. It's kind of... rare around here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nice, actually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have no idea. I'm kind of a magnet for these jerk-offs. They charm me, and I fall for it, and at some point they just... never call me again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand. Look at you. Who wouldn't call you again? She looks up. It's not a line, it's a genuine compliment. She smiles warmly. Holy shit, Cal is in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... what were you `supposed' to do next?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, eventually I'm `supposed' to ask you if you want to get out of here. Actually no, I'm supposed to tell you, confidently, that you should come home with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you give it a shot, see what happens?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal looks up, surprised. He clears his throat, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're very pretty, Kate. And I can't tell if you're being serious, but I think you should come home with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask me again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal smiles and leans forward, faux-confident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
