dialogues.text: ... and now, to introduce the  first student speaker: our very own English teacher Kate Thompson!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal's former conquest steps onto stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy looks away, clearly uncomfortable at the teacher's  presence. She accidentally catches Cal's eye. Awkward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our next speaker is not only the class salutatorian, but he's also one of the most...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spirited... young men, I've ever had the pleasure of teaching. Ladies and gentlemen: Robbie Weaver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie takes the stage to APPLAUSE. This is not the same  kid we've come to love. There's something different in  his face. He's been broken. He spots JESSICA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a bit monotone)  Thank you, Mrs. Thompson.  Welcome, Class of 2011.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't really sure what I wanted  to talk about today. Mrs.  Thompson said it might be good to  talk about growing up and getting  older and stuff. So I guess I'll  talk about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal watches, concerned. Where's his son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I grew up a lot this year, I  think. I used to think that  growing up meant really growing.  Like getting taller and bigger.  But now I think that growing up  just makes you smaller. Your  dreams get smaller, and what you  want gets smaller...  (beat, then)  I grew an inch and a half this  year, but I feel a lot smaller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal sits forward, getting increasingly concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was in love. And I know that  makes parents laugh because I'm  only thirteen but whatever, I was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believed that there was one true  love for everyone, and if you  fought for that person, your one  true love would always work out.  But that's not how it works. It  sounded good when I was younger,  but... it's just not how it works.  There's no such thing as one true  love for everyo--

dialogues.speaker: CAL, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie turns. Cal is STANDING in the middle of the  crowd. Everyone turns to look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.  (awkward, to crowd)  Hi, everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. No one knows what to do. Cal is suddenly  really uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I have a word with my son?  It'll just take a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal tries to extricate himself from his row. He steps  over people, squeezes by people, almost trips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally clear, he gathers himself, and tries to keep his  dignity as he marches down the aisle -- past his family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie comes to the front of the stage, bends down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie's eyes well up with tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was wrong, Dad. There's no such  thing as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal turns toward the crowd, announces:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My son's graduation speech sucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GASPS from the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now standing, alone, front and center in front of an  entire eighth grade graduation ceremony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks behind him at the panel of TEACHERS. MRS.  THOMPSON discreetly gives Cal the finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In fairness, I don't know where he  was going but I think we can all  agree it was heading in a pretty  depressing direction. And I  basically wrote it for him. I  mean, I didn't literally write it  but I sure as hell influenced it,  and the kid's already a spitting  image of his mother and I'll be  damned if this is what he's going  to get from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People squirm, uncomfortable. This is a train wreck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My son -- not him, my actual son --  he believes in grand romantic  gestures. He believes that people  have soulmates. And we always  want to tell our thirteen-year-  olds that they're wrong, that `one  day you'll understand, young man.'  But maybe it should be the other  way around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at Tracy, out in the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I met my soulmate when I was  fifteen years old. Our first  date, we went for ice cream.  After, my dad started teasing me  about my `first date' the way dads  do. And I told him: `stop making  a big deal, Dad. I'm going to go  on lots of dates with plenty of  girls.' That was the first time I  ever lied to my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I met my soulmate when I was  fifteen years old. And I have  loved her with everything I have  for every minute, of every day,  ever since she let me buy her that  first mint chip ice cream. I have  loved her through the birth of our  three perfect children, and I have  loved her even as I've hated her --  only married couples can truly  understand that one. And I don't  know what will wind up happening  with us -- I don't, Robbie, I'm  sorry I can't give you that -- but  I promise you this: I will never  stop trying. When you find `the  one' you never give up trying...  and I love you, my amazing boy,  for reminding me of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie hugs his father as the crowd reacts. Cal kisses  his son on the head, then motions towards the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie grabs it with newfound gusto and announces:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still love you, Jessica! I've  loved you since the first time you  changed my sister's diaper! I've  loved you since...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd reacts (LAUGHS, CHEERS, etc.) as Robbie  continues. Cal stands back and smiles. His boy is back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ceremony is over. Robbie heads over to his family.  They hug him, kiss him. Cal approaches Hannah and Jacob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Nanna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles at her, adoring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My perfect girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses her forehead, turns to Jacob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already ordered a gun. I'm not  kidding. I ordered a Colt .45 on  a shady internet site, I can show  you the receipt. If you hurt her,  I am prepared to shoot you in the  face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal, I'm not going to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, Jacob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob shuts up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. I like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacob smiles, shakes hands with Cal. Cal notices:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a new shirt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah took me to the Gap. It's  actually not as bad as I thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not, Cal. It's the Gap.  I got this at Nordstrom's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And like that... order is restored in the universe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who approaches Jessica.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was nice of you to come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't have missed it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awkward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, how are things with your dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strained. I took a summer internship up at Stanford, gonna  head up there early. Figure it can't hurt to get out of his line of sight for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, probably a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were a good baby-sitter, Jessica. I'm sorry if I made you uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds out his hand, to shake, formally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait: I thought you weren't  giving up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not. But I figure: you like  my dad, and one day I'll look like my dad, so I'll just come for you then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jessica smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a good plan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks over her shoulder, reaches into her purse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until then: a little graduation gift. To help get you through high school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands him something in an ENVELOPE: the same type of envelope she once used for...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie peeks inside. His eyes BUG OUT. Jessica kisses him, sweetly, on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take care, Robbie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie watches her go. Love-struck once more. Cal steps  up next to his son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay, buddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am now, Dad. I am now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie runs off to join his friends. Cal smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: I'm terrified of what's going to  become of him once he hits  puberty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal turns, Tracy has been watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We might have to lock him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy smiles. Cal walks over toward her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gave a good eighth grade  graduation speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been working on it for thirty  years, so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She LAUGHS, then... quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think we can ever come back  from all this, Cal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I'd like to try  though. I know I'd like to try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things are just so messed up. And  it's been such a strange year.  I've been in such a strange place.  And we have all these problems, so  many problems I've lost count, but  at the end of the day, I mean, the  only thing I know --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops herself, emotional. Then, simply:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am just so glad you took me for  that ice cream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal smiles. They share the moment in silence. And then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was rocky road by the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they JOKE and ARGUE about what flavor the ice cream  was, we PULL BACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off to the side, Robbie steps away from his friends and  watches them enjoy one another's company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles.
